text.lat: 87.— Gyges olim quidam, hiante terra post magnos quosdam imbres, descendit in illum hiatum, aeneumque equum conspexit. Huius in lateribus fores erant: his apertis, hominis mortui vidit corpus mira magnitudine, annulum aureum in digito habentis. Annulum ipse induit (erat autem servus regis), tum in concilium se servorum recepit. Ibi palam eius annuli in manum convertens, a nullo videbatur; ipse autem omnia videbat: idem annulum in locum restituit, tum rursus videbatur. Itaque, hac occasione annuli usus, regem dominum interfecit, et inimicos sustulit: nec in his facinoribus eum quisquam videre potuit. Sic annuli ope rex Lydiae factus est.
text.eng: 87.— A certain Gyges once, as the ground gaped open after some great rains, descended into this chasm and noticed a bronze horse. In its sides were doors: upon opening these, he saw the body of a dead man of remarkable size, bearing a golden ring on its finger. He himself put on the ring (he was a slave of the king), then entered the gathering of the servants. There, by turning the bezel of that ring in his hand, he was seen by no one; yet he saw everything himself: he restored the ring to its place and was then seen again. So, using this advantage of the ring, he killed the king, his master, and removed his enemies; yet no one could see him committing these crimes. By the ring's power, thus, he became the king of Lydia.
